file_content.text: Indeed.
Something you want? An autograph? A diagram on a napkin?
Distractions are the bane of genius, you know.
I never thought I'd say it, but good riddance to Nar Shaddaa. Nobody on that wretched moon has a speck of imagination.
Take my little business. If I wasn't building devices to cheat the casinos, I was being nagged for new weapons.
I imagine only heavily-armed cheaters prosper on Nar Shaddaa.
By the same people, I bet.
Quite. Everyone has a system, few have an escape plan.
So being sought out and admired for creating wonders of technology; that meant nothing to you?
Admit it, you love your work.
You do have a way with words, my dear.
Well. I suppose there were compensations.
Your talents could have found you a home anywhere in the galaxy, if you wanted to leave.
Why didn't you just leave?
Oh, Nar Shaddaa has benefits, like opportunities to "acquire" new property. Sadly everyone else is thinking the same thing.
Now, we get to travel in the most darling ship.
Although... I just can't bear your ship's computer architecture. It's so frumpy. Mind if I give it a little flair?
If it makes you feel more welcome, go ahead.
Feel free.
Oh good! I know just where to start: that horrible algorithm for the hyperdrive.
Will this "flair" interfere with it being completely operational?
"Flair" sounds ominous.
No no, don't you worry about a thing.
Holiday has quite the talent for making herself at home. Better leave her to it.
I don't want you "improving" my ship without permission. Understand?
No. Leave it alone.
Hmph. Spoilsport.
Now. I'm sure there are more... stimulating matters for you to attend to.
So! Lead on, Jedi.
Jedi, Holiday and I have an announcement to make.
I don't think I've ever seen you looking so resolute.
This looks serious.
I'm intrigued.
Then I hope it's a lovely wedding, and you have a dozen holo-children.
You're getting married?
Oh, Tharan, that's a thought.
Moving along!
We've become rather... addicted to the adventuring life. So we've decided to stay with you, indefinitely.
And my projected lifespan is long enough to keep you, and any... little Jedi, out of trouble.
Thank you both, very much.
I'm flattered.
Trouble is eternal. I'll be glad to have you.
It's good to have friends.
I assure you, there will be no "little Jedi" for you to worry about.
Children? Not a chance.
Aw. I wanted to be someone's Aunt Holiday.
We're getting off topic, my dear.
Wherever you go, you can always rely on Holiday and myself.
That's a promise.
It appears I have secured my place in scientific history. As a laughing-stock.
There I stood at the podium, my fellow scientists hanging on my every word. I had only to turn on the Vandrayk Generator.
But I couldn't do it. I saw Holiday, and... I couldn't. When I tried to explain, I was booed off the stage.
You're helping the person you care for, at the cost of your own dream.
You did it for Holiday.
Indeed. Thank you, for giving me perspective.
You're a better scientist than all of them put together.
The Club doesn't deserve you.
Such a gracious sentiment. Thank you.
That's very kind of you.
Can't you just enter again next year?
There'll be other symposiums.
I suspect I may be blacklisted, now. But, we shall see.
Now, Holiday. I think the core is ready. We can begin the installation.
Tharan, I'm... scared. What if it changes me? What if I don't love you any more?
Holiday. I am a fool, dancing in your shadow. But whether you favor me or not, I will always belong to you.
Tharan... Install it now. Before I change my mind.
Stacks two and three reinitializing. Transfer. Transfer.
Can you hear me? Is everything all right?
Holiday?
Whatever you're doing isn't helping her.
Stop this immediately.
Something's wrong.
Holiday, please speak to me.
Ahem! Oh my, how embarrassing. That core's potent stuff.
Has the core made any difference yet?
How do you feel?
You had us worried for a moment.
What a relief.
You're tougher than you look, Holiday.
I knew you'd be fine.
I've... got more space. Like there's huge empty rooms waiting to fill up. It's exciting!
It'll take time for the change to fully propagate--Holiday's systems are very complex.
But in the end, her personality and sentience will increase. Exponentially. I hope we'll be able to keep up.
My work is finally complete. The Vandrayk Generator. Dare I say, a masterpiece among masterpieces.
Tharan, I'm so proud of you! I think I'm going to cry.
Yes, well done, but perhaps you should sit down for a minute.
You look exhausted, Tharan.
There'll be time for a week-long sleep later.
You've made scientific history today.
This is a great achievement.
But it won't do any good sitting on the ship like a paperweight.
Don't my contributions count for anything?
What about me? I helped.
Of course, of course. Your moral support was... er, invaluable.
The Lumenatus Club symposium only runs for a day. I must secure the generator for transport--its core needs to be perfectly shielded.
The core is very sensitive to nearby electronic systems, you see. Its processes could... its...
The core's processes could what?
Go on.
What's the matter?
Start making sense.
Jedi, I am a complete idiot. The core of my Vandrayk Generator could have an application that I never considered. For Holiday.
If I linked that core to Holiday's central processor, it could increase her sentience by a factor of ten. Or more!
I thought this core was too fragile to be used more than once.
Won't the core be destroyed?
In the Vandrayk Generator, yes. But Holiday's systems are very different, far more efficient.
How would Holiday change if you gave her this core?
What would that mean for her?
She'd be able to transcend most of her remaining technical limitations. Her slicing capability could increase--her personality would evolve.
But if I remove the core, my Vandrayk Generator is useless. I won't have a hope of winning the symposium.
Without the core, there's no Vandrayk Generator. You'll have nothing to demonstrate at the symposium.
But you'd lose your generator.
Everyone is waiting to see my work. Jedi, even for Holiday I can't... Winning the symposium is my dream!
Glory is transient. Think about what, and who, really matters to you.
Give the core to Holiday.
This is your future we're discussing. You deserve a say.
Holiday, what do you want?
But... but Tharan's upset. I just want him to be happy.
Keep the core for your Vandrayk Generator. Prove to the Lumenatus Club you're the finest scientist in the galaxy.
Then use the generator. Win.
You're right! I don't need the core. But someone has to show those stuffy old bores what real genius is!
There's no time to decide, the symposium's starting soon. The entire Lumenatus Club is expecting me.
I have to attend. I... I'll be back soon.
Er, what? Oh! Please excuse me, Jedi.
The last pieces of the Vandrayk Generator must have a precise exposure to the ship's engine core. I'll be right back!
Jedi, could I please talk to you for a minute? It's... it's about Tharan.
Something isn't quite right with him.
He does seem distracted.
Don't be upset. Just say what's on your mind.
I'm here to help.
You're so kind.
Tharan, always Tharan. Can't you think about anything else?
It always is, with you.
I need help, and you just want to be mean to me.
Tharan's been working so hard for the symposium. It's all he talks about.
It's just so rare for him to get a real challenge. I don't think he's handling it very well.
Please, he listens to you. Is there anything you can do?
I'll watch out for Tharan, and step in if things go too far.
I'll keep an eye on him.
Oh, thank you.
Having his genius tested will teach Tharan more than years of success.
This may be good for Tharan.
I hope that's true.
You're a good friend to us, Jedi. Both me and my sweet Tharan.
Holiday, did Tharan reprogram you to fall in love with him, or is it your choice?
Are your feelings a program?
Ha. Well, what makes "real" people like you fall in love, hmm?
It's different for you. Your personality can be reprogrammed, mine can't.
But you're a unique case.
I suppose I can't answer that question.
I... don't know.
I use software to feel, but feelings are more than that. Like your feelings are more than... reacting chemicals.
A willingness to overlook the faults of others, and hope they do the same for you.
Mutual delusion.
Oh, Jedi. That's so sad.
I love Tharan. So does it matter where that feeling came from? Nope. Not one bit.
It's my pleasure.
Compared to keeping you two happy, the Jedi Trials were simple.
You've become a real project.
The galaxy doesn't revolve around you and Tharan. Other people have problems too.
No. And stop being selfish.
Sometimes you're a real sourpuss.
Just in time! A moment longer and the irradiation would have gone too far.
Tharan, honey, why don't you take a break? With me?
Hmm? No, no. Too much to do. Sorry, Jedi, I'll speak to you another time.
I do believe I'm really feeling the benefits of some fresh air and exercise. Who would have thought?
And your delightful company has been most beneficial.
Can't you ever simply talk to me?
More sweet-talk, I see.
Loveliness is rare. Is it so bad to be appreciated?
And the company of a true intellectual equal hasn't hurt either.
I'm glad I met you, Tharan.
You're good company too.
Thank you.
So next time you complain about the agony of genius, I'll know you're full of nonsense.
"Equal"? I'll remember that.
Blast my thoughtless candor.
I've refitted my equipment, and streamlined Holiday's programming even further. Hopefully, we should be of greater use to you.
Besides, I should showcase my best work. Even in the thick of battle, you never know who's watching.
Do you, er, have a moment?
I thought you'd be hard at work.
How's the project coming?
Oh, it's fine. Everything's absolutely fine.
If you want to talk, I'm always happy to listen.
Of course.
You are a rare comfort in difficult times.
You're a good friend, Jedi.
You seem nervous.
Ah, the rarefied awareness of the female.
Ah, the instant perceptiveness of a Jedi.
I just spoke to Maven Wedder, head of the Lumenatus Club. The symposium's coming up very soon.
He said he's heard rumors about my Vandrayk Generator. Everyone's very... excited.
You don't sound especially happy.
But you're not.
I thought you wanted them to recognize your talents.
Isn't that a good thing?
Of course I do!
If they know the truth, they must realize they don't have a hope of winning.
Jealous is more likely.
I'm... not so sure.
I've nearly finished the generator, but Shorjin Challas was right. When I turn it on, its core will be destroyed.
That core is irreplaceable. Meaning, I have no way to test the generator before the symposium.
Jedi, to be truly accepted by the scientific community's elite... I can't lose when I'm so close.
When you crave something too much, desire often serves to blind you.
Needing to win causes failure.
And what if it's the only thing you've ever wanted?
You Jedi can avoid the searing highs and lows of success and failure. I have no such luxury.
You're going to win that symposium, and be written about in scientific journals from here to Geonosis.
Be calm. It'll be fine.
My dear Jedi. I can always count on your words of wisdom.
Your confidence is... a great comfort. Thank you.
You'll certainly lose if you're too overwrought to work.
Fretting won't help.
Yes. Only the Gen'Dai flourish as a bundle of nerves, and they're all nervous tissue to begin with.
I stand poised on the brink of finally proving my worth. The view is... dizzying. But so is the drop.
It's gratifying to know the security systems at my store are still intact.
Shorjin Challas sends his regards, by the way. Charming fellow. Wrote his thesis on planetary shielding mechanics.
It sounds like you've made a friend.
A real colleague, then.
He was kind enough to express some concerns, about the components he was trading with me.
Was Shorjin willing to trade with you?
Did you get what you needed?
Indeed. In fact, we got to talking, and he brought an issue to my attention.
Remember, you'll be competing against him later at the symposium.
Don't forget he's a rival.
Oh. I'd quite forgotten that. Still, Shorjin actually had some salient advice to offer.
Shorjin's components will certainly build the core of the Vandrayk Generator, but he claimed the stress of its operation will soon burn them out.
My Vandrayk Generator will work. But it will work for a minute, at most, before it is destroyed forever.
Your generator's going to be a landmark discovery. Is there nothing we can do?
Surely we can save it.
This must be hard on you.
If the generator will break the moment you turn it on, what's the use of making one?
Then all this was pointless.
The Vandrayk Generator is an impossible machine, Jedi. To make an impossible machine work at all is a scientific marvel.
A moment's operation should be enough to win the symposium. But after that...
Forgive me, Jedi, I should double-check Shorjin's calculations. There may be something else I've overlooked.
The Vandrayk Generator is finally taking shape. We're a step closer to victory at the symposium!
Now we begin the most crucial stage--the generator's core. And another Lumenatus Club member, Shorjin Challas, has offered to help with that.
That's very generous of him.
What a kind gesture.
True. Plus he doesn't know his entry is doomed to fail against mine.
Isn't Shorjin taking part in the symposium too?
But you're competitors.
Until the symposium itself we're brothers in science. Besides, whatever his entry is, it can't possibly compete.
This might be a ruse to copy the Vandrayk Generator.
He could steal your idea.
Copying a masterpiece isn't so easy, Jedi.
Shorjin wants to trade some exo-tech for components I need. But, I left my juicier exo-tech artifacts back at my store.
You'll pardon me if I take a brief trip home to make the trade? We shan't be away for long.
This Shorjin is a stranger. I should come with you.
You shouldn't go alone.
A kind offer, but Shorjin seems harmless. If I can't defend myself in my own store, I have greater problems than being attacked.
Don't you worry, Jedi. No one hurts my Tharan while I'm around.
Is there a particular piece that Shorjin is interested in?
So what tech are you trading?
Nothing. A mere technological curiosity. It's perfectly legal, in several star systems.
Don't start gambling and end up too poor for a shuttle back.
Stay out of the casinos.
Hopefully Shorjin will have all the components I need. The Vandrayk Generator's core is crucial to this entire endeavor.
The equations are done, and we're about to start building the actual Vandrayk Generator itself.
But we're finding components hard to come by. My suppliers are being ludicrously unreasonable. What's an unpaid bill here or there?
If only I could regain my suppliers' favor. With, say, a note promising payment will be made. Signed by someone trustworthy.
You're hoping I'll sign this note and get you out of this mess.
You mean me, don't you?
No one's more honorable than Qyzen. Let's ask him.
Well, Qyzen's trustworthy....
Jedi, don't be silly, you know who he means.
I know what you're asking, and the answer is no.
I'm not signing it.
You have the power to do me an immense kindness with one little signature. I'd be eternally grateful.
Give me the note and I'll guarantee payment for you.
All right, I'll sign it.
Settling your debts will improve your reputation, and your suppliers will be more helpful.
You should pay your bills.
That'll take every credit I possess! Do you want me destitute?
If it's really going to cost that much, you'll need time to get the money together.
Fine, I'll sign your note.
Such generosity. I promise, this is the last time I will intrude upon you.
Thank you. I'll have the parts I need in no time.
Would you rather be a poor man with a Vandrayk Generator, or a rich man whose dreams are unfulfilled?
But you'll win the symposium.
Blasted Jedi logic!
If you cut back on your lifestyle, I'm sure you'll survive.
Try being more frugal.
That's so unfair!
If you won't help, bankruptcy may be my only salvation. I'd better get it over with.
You created this situation, get yourself out of it.
No. This is your own fault.
I come to you in my hour of need and get turned away.
I hope the history of scientific progress is kind to you, Jedi.
We've made some progress on the Vandrayk Generator.
The initial equations have been... difficult, but with Holiday's help, I'm almost ready to progress.
I've just hit a minor obstacle. I find myself needing your help, dear Jedi.
I've just hit one small obstacle, and I'm sure you and I can handle that.
If I can do something to make your generator a success, just ask.
Anything to help the project.
Go on.
I'm suspicious already.
It's a moment's diversion, nothing more.
I find myself in need of inspiration. On Nar Shaddaa, a particular spiced wine was a marvelous tonic.
A friend has offered to send me a case, if I get him an audience with the Jedi Council.
So my role is to facilitate this audience.
And I'm to arrange it.
It's such a small favor. Practically insulting to your talents.
Why does he want to speak to the Council?
An audience? What for?
He's searching for new trade routes, I believe.
If he was a true friend, he would just send you the wine.
How "friendly" of him.
He sees an opportunity, there's nothing wrong with that.
Now, I have a message for the Council, ready for your signature. What do you say?
The Council won't mind, I'm sure.
I'll sign it.
You are a paragon of compassion and understanding.
Excellent! I'll send word to him at once.
My case of wine should arrive forthwith, and all shall be well. Thank you.
Don't fall back into bad habits. If you wish, I can teach you a technique to improve your mental discipline.
No, but I'll help you focus.
My "bad habits" and I have come far together without Jedi navel-gazing.
Oh, I'll try it. On the condition that you arrange the audience if it's not a success.
How interesting. I... Do excuse me, Jedi, I think I see where I've been going wrong.
Lounging around drinking spiced wine isn't going to win the symposium, whatever your excuse.
No. Get back to work.
This is no "excuse". The wellspring of genius must be carefully nurtured.
If my request has fallen on stony ground, I suppose my work is now my only consolation.
Do you have time for a chat with your fellow intellectuals?
We've been trying to think of the absolute perfect entry for the Lumenatus Club's symposium.
Nothing we've come up with has quite the spectacular edge I'm looking for. Any ideas?
You could try curing a disease, or creating tech to restore war-devastated planets.
Something to help people.
That sounds like a lot of hard work.
Holiday's a technological marvel, and unique. Why not submit her?
What about Holiday?
No, no! What if they wanted to examine her--disassemble her? No, Holiday's out of the question.
Defense technology would be impressive. Something powerful enough to, say, destroy a whole Imperial fleet?
A super-weapon.
Building weapons of that caliber attracts tiresome attention.
Still, you're on the right track. I need an unprecedented creation. Something no one else could possibly be making.
Yes.... perfect. I'll build a Vandrayk Generator. It was theorized by Doctor Gorman Vandrayk centuries ago, but never realized.
As I recall, a Vandrayk Generator runs on a form of energy that doesn't exist.
That's an impossible machine.
A minor setback.
Will you be done in time for the symposium?
How long will that take?
Considering the Vandrayk Generator is theoretically impossible... I hope so.
Sounds good, as long as this generator has benefits beyond winning a rosette.
I hope it's useful.
Well, theoretically, a Vandrayk Generator is an impossible machine. So who knows what a working one could do?
Besides, old Gorman Vandrayk never knew about exo-tech. And he didn't have me to help!
A functioning Vandrayk Generator would prove a dozen theories. And cement my place in scientific history.
Such a project! Sorry, Jedi, I really must get started.
Success! Our mystery capsule has finally yielded its secrets!
Converting the chemical to a gas was the ticket. We managed to fill the capsule.
And all these words started glowing on the inside. We found the real message! Isn't that super?
You must be very proud of yourselves.
Congratulations!
It gets better.
Please tell me we've finally got an answer.
What does it say?
I won't know until I hear it.
The message is from the Lumenatus Club, a veritable "who's who" of the galaxy's finest scientific minds. An invitation to join them.
The Lumenatus Club only accepts the best. The pioneers in their field. All these years in obscurity, and my genius has finally been recognized!
This all seems rather extravagant for a simple invitation.
But why the secret message?
A test, obviously. The Lumenatus Club's final exam, as it were.
You must be very proud.
These scientists must keep a low profile.
I've never heard of this Club.
There's no point being an elite group if any riffraff can apply to join.
This means I can enter the Club's annual symposium--my creations against those of my fellow scientists.
The symposium winner will be the darling of the Lumenatus Club. It wouldn't be unreasonable to consider them the greatest scientist in the galaxy.
This invitation is a great honor, but don't let it go to your head.
Don't over-reach yourself.
Over-confidence is for lesser men.
You'll need something truly special to stand a chance of winning.
It'll be quite the challenge.
I see where this is going.
I think universal adoration and the symposium's grand prize are worth pursuing, don't you?
Pardon me, Jedi. I must accept the Club's invitation, then start thinking of the finest symposium entry ever created.
I have unfortunate news.
I regret that our liaison must... come to an end.
So Holiday has spoken to you.
Holo-girlfriend found out?
Our encounter was short, but sweet. Thank you.
I enjoyed the time we had.
You are most welcome. But our troubles don't end there.
We work well together. Why should we let anything interfere?
I don't accept that.
An agreement has been reached. I cease any advances to you, and in return, Holiday will not... electrify my bunk at random intervals.
Our tragic parting only compounds my current troubles.
Do you remember our mystery capsule, and the letter? Holiday made the chemical, just as she promised.
I thought applying it to the letter was the answer. But when I tried, it completely dissolved. We are left only with vapors.
What a shame. You and Holiday worked so hard on this.
I'm sorry.
Poor Holiday blames herself--she shut herself down for a long cry.
There must be something else you can try.
Don't give up.
That chemical is the answer, I know it! But without another lead... Wait!
That letter was our only lead to whatever's going on here.
Now we'll never solve this.
No. Not our only lead, Jedi!
The capsule the letter came in. I kept it to study the lock. I could apply the chemical to that instead!
One clue's already gone up in smoke. What happens if we lose the capsule?
And if that dissolves too?
Then I'll eat this blasted chemical, and see if that does anything.
Let me lend a hand.
Your generosity does you credit, but I have everything under control.
Your approach to science is quite... unique, Tharan.
Here we go again.
Holiday? Come back online, my dear, we have a new avenue of enquiry!
This is absolutely intolerable.
I finally get that blasted capsule's lock open, and the letter inside? Pure gibberish.
Jedi, you can make this all better, can't you?
Listen to this. "A, H, three, two, O, S, H, four..." And that's just one line!
The message is probably encrypted.
Sounds like a code.
Yes, that occurred to me too. But all our deciphering attempts have failed.
Perhaps some letters are missing, or distorted somehow.
It could be damaged.
No, the writing is clear as day. But its meaning is utter nonsense.
Maybe you've attracted a mechanical admirer.
A droid's love poem?
I know my limits, Jedi.
"A.H. three." Three, three... ah. This isn't a message, it's a chemical formula!
And the letter itself smells strange. I thought it was the capsule. But what if applying the chemical to the letter had some effect?
That formula looks very complex, and you don't have a laboratory.
Can you make this chemical?
Hmm. An excellent point.
We'll never know if we don't try.
Let's just do it.
Spoken like a true scientist.
Don't get carried away. We still don't know who it's from, or what they want.
This is all very suspicious.
What harm could one little letter do?
Oh! Oh! Let me make that chemical! I can do it in a snap, and I simply have to know what's on that letter!
I'll get started right away!
At last, an answer. However do you do it? Your very presence sparks my inspiration.
You didn't need me to solve this.
You'd have got it eventually.
I will not hear a lovely woman denigrate her gifts.
Does my presence spark anything else?
[Flirt] Just inspiration?
You bring out the very best in me, Jedi--you have ever since Nar Shaddaa.
Let me express my gratitude properly. In private, perhaps.
Do you say that to every woman who's nearby when you get an idea?
That's a cheap line.
Now I've offended you. Let me make amends.
Some time to ourselves, in private, could smooth over this little misunderstanding.
There's already a woman in your life, Tharan.
What about Holiday?
What Holiday and I have is... complex. It has its pleasures.
But there are simpler pleasures. No less valuable, but... unconnected. So there's no need for concern.
Even so, I don't want to risk hurting Holiday. I'm sorry.
No, I won't do this to her.
Then we were not to be? I... Please, excuse me.
Let no one say I didn't ask.
I was just checking.
And I won't tell if you don't.
She'll never know, anyway.
You really are full of good ideas.
I'd enjoy that.
Then let's find somewhere to get acquainted.
You are a rare find in this galaxy.
I regret that I must leave such delectable company so soon, but work calls. Until later, my Jedi.
I don't think so. Besides, you have a chemical to synthesize.
Don't you have work to do?
Ah. Yes. Thank you for the reminder.
Thank you for the inspiration, Jedi. Please excuse us, there's so much to do.
Ah, excellent!
We have a mystery. A package was hand-delivered to the ship. No name--aside from mine--no return address.
The package contained a letter on flimsiplast, sealed inside a glass capsule. Nothing else.
Maybe the letter has some answers.
So open it.
How intriguing.
The capsule has a marvelously puzzling lock, I've never seen such craftsmanship.
We should get rid of it, just in case.
It's likely dangerous.
But the lock on this capsule is a work of art, I can't destroy it.
Once I get it open and read the letter, hopefully I can assuage my curiosity.
This is so exciting! I wonder who it's from.
Tharan's technological work is famous. Perhaps someone is trying to get his attention.
Maybe it's from a fan.
I wouldn't be surprised if someone's demanding money.
Could be a blackmailer.
Few blackmailers are this creative. Trust me.
Probably some old flame getting revenge on Tharan.
An ex-girlfriend's prank?
They know better than to try getting Tharan's attention again.
I'll get to work on this lock. If you're right, we'll know soon enough.
Just one moment, Jedi.
Holiday's latest viral safeguards need to upload--quite a weighty update this week.
Mm-hm, someone's been busy. I should give this my full attention. Goodnight!
Ah, Holiday. You are unique indeed.
You and Holiday clearly care for each other.
You two seem very close.
My affections are all-encompassing, Jedi. Though Holiday is special.
Naturally. She's proof that science and beauty can coexist.
She mentioned being more than a hologram, but little else.
What is Holiday, again?
Holiday? She's a holographic life form. "Alive" in all important ways, but without the inconveniences of a physical body.
However much attention you lavish on her, Holiday's still just an image.
She's not real, you know.
I thought a Jedi would be more considerate of one's metaphysical state.
Her former owner never appreciated Holiday's potential. That's a Hutt for you.
Holiday's last owner was a Hutt, then.
Sounds intriguing.
You'd crossed paths with the Hutt Cartel before we met?
Was he on Nar Shaddaa?
Oh, no. I encountered him on Hutta.
Glorzo, his name was. He collected rare technology, but he thought Holiday was just a novelty hologram. Imagine.
I made a generous offer, but some scavenger had already struck a deal for her. So, Glorzo saw the chance for a little fun.
You make a good living. How could a simple scavenger compete with your funds?
Why not make a higher offer?
I was... between clients, and Hutta has expensive diversions.
Go on.
Hutts have strange ideas about what constitutes "entertainment."
Never a good thing to hear.
Glorzo proposed a contest. The scavenger and I would head into the Vaal asteroid field--hopefully surviving more than two minutes.
The first to bring back a stone from the Rukabi Major asteroid would win dear Holiday.
I hear approaching Rukabi Major is suicidal. There's too much debris around it.
That's no mean feat.
This contest hardly seems fair.
By risking your life?
Of course not. How could Glorzo have fun if it was fair?
Holiday isn't in the scavenger's hands, so I can guess how it ended.
And clearly, you won.
I had the last laugh. Clever piloting is no match for knowing certain navigational algorithms.
I got the stone, returned days before the scavenger, and exchanged it for sweet Holiday.
So you heroically rescued Holiday from the grip of a cruel Hutt, and won her heart.
A very chivalrous rescue.
Someday it'll make an excellent holonovel.
I imagine your competitor wasn't happy about being beaten.
And the scavenger?
Pfft. What do I care? Holiday was safe.
That's the most ridiculous story I've ever heard.
I don't believe a word.
Don't draw this out more than you need to.
Give me the short version.
Suffice to say, then, that I won Holiday in a little wager from a Hutt named Glorzo.
My competitor, some scavenger from the Outer Rim, wasn't too happy to lose Holiday. But such is life.
Still, this is all past. And you, my Jedi, have provided a most invigorating change from my usual activities.
That's very gracious.
Thank you.
Sadly, I often find words inadequate to fully express myself.
I'd prefer to finish this conversation here. You know there's someone else.
Enough. I'm spoken for.
Though it pains me to acknowledge it. Very well.
I didn't realize my company was so stimulating.
[Flirt] Oh really?
Indeed. Who knows what ideas you may inspire.
Stop trying to sweet-talk me.
I'm not "your" Jedi.
A mere slip of the tongue. I'll guard it more carefully in future.
Ah, but what's the past to the present? And we have things to do.
Could I discuss something with you? Preferably on the ship?
Jedi, when you're free, could I have a moment of your time?
So much to attend to.
Just one moment, Jedi.
Moving along!
So! Lead on, Jedi.
I do believe I'm really feeling the benefits of some fresh air and exercise. Who would have thought?
Business before pleasure, I suppose.
Holiday, darling, a little help?
We'll endeavor not to disappoint.
Rest assured, I have every intention of staying out of trouble.
The curse of being exemplary--being needed. Very well.
Why are people on this world so unreasonable?
We're ready when you are, Jedi.
Still, much as I appreciate the change of pace, we really should be going.
Jedi, for once, could we please go somewhere pleasant?
